The presidential tracking poll reflects a slight change of wording from previous surveys

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN10A0PS	Clinton secures Mark Cuban's endorsement in Pittsburgh	"
By Amanda Becker
PITTSBURGH
column2: Pa. - Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton toured the U.S. Rust Belt on Saturday
column3: promising to reject bad international trade deals during a factory visit and securing the endorsement of investor Mark Cuban at a Pittsburgh rally.The Dallas Mavericks owner
column4: who said as recently as last month that there was a ""good chance"" he would vote for Donald Trump
column5: instead criticized the Republican nominee's leadership in front of an energetic crowd.""Leadership is not yelling and screaming and intimidating
column6: Cuban said.""You know what we call a person like that in Pittsburgh? A jagoff!"" Cuban added
column7: using disparaging Pittsburgh slang.Cuban had spoken with Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta several times in recent weeks and called him on Thursday to say he was ready to endorse Clinton
column9: along with her running-mate Tim Kaine
column11: is on a three-day tour of Pennsylvania and Ohio after becoming the first woman to accept a major U.S. party's presidential nomination at the Democratic convention in Philadelphia on Thursday.

column1: Pennsylvania and Ohio are two states in the U.S. Rust Belt that are dealing with job losses caused by the decline in U.S. manufacturing. Neither leans heavily in favor of either political party but both voted for Obama in 2008 and 2012. Trump has zeroed in on white
column2: working-class voters in the region as critical to his campaign and plans to visit both states early next week. In a visit earlier on Saturday to Johnstown Wire Technologies in Johnstown
column3: Pennsylvania
column4: Clinton told the largely union crowd there that she would create good-paying jobs by investing in infrastructure and reject a pending Asia trade deal that has become a flashpoint in the U.S. presidential campaign.""We are going to say 'no' to unfair trade deals
column5: we're going to stand up to China
column6: Clinton said.

column1: I feel strongly about this and I need your help
column2: she added.The pending Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP) negotiated by President Barack Obama has drawn criticism from both Clinton and Trump.Clinton says it does not do enough to protect U.S. workers. Trump has said he would rip it up and questioned whether Clinton would keep her stance if she wins the Nov. 8 presidential election.

column1: Leo Gerard
column2: the president of the United Steelworkers
column3: which represents roughly 200 of the 260 workers employed by Johnstown Wire Technologies
column4: assured the crowd in his introduction of Clinton that Republicans have been ""telling lies"" about Clinton's stance on the deal. Cambria County
column5: where Johnstown Wire Technologies is based
column6: is 94-percent white and has a median household income of $42
column7: 000.Clinton and Kaine will continue their jobs-focused tour that began in Philadelphia
column8: continuing on to Youngstown and Columbus. They are trying to contrast their plan to use infrastructure investments to create jobs with that of Trump
column9: whom Clinton said Friday has a ""downbeat vision of America.""""We are visiting places that prove what Americans can do
column10: Clinton said in Johnstown. ""This country and our people have what it takes to get ahead and stay ahead if they have the leadership that gives us that chance."" (Reporting by Amanda Becker; Editing by Sandra Maler)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-democrats-investigation-exc-idUSKCN1092HK	Exclusive: Clinton campaign also hacked in attacks on Democrats	"
By Mark Hosenball
column2: Joseph Menn and John Walcott

column1: | WASHINGTON/SAN FRANCISCO
WASHINGTON/SAN FRANCISCO A computer network used by Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton's campaign was hacked as part of a broad cyber attack on Democratic political organizations
column2: people familiar with the matter told Reuters.The latest attack
column3: which was disclosed to Reuters on Friday
column4: follows two other hacks on the Democratic National Committee
column5: or DNC
column6: and the party's fundraising committee for candidates for the U.S. House of Representatives.A Clinton campaign spokesman said in a statement late on Friday that an analytics data program maintained by the DNC and used by the campaign and a number of other entities ""was accessed as part of the DNC hack.""""Our campaign computer system has been under review by outside cyber security experts. To date
column7: they have found no evidence that our internal systems have been compromised
column8: said Clinton campaign spokesman Nick Merrill.Later
column9: a campaign official said hackers had access to the analytics program's server for approximately five days. The analytics data program is one of many systems the campaign accesses to conduct voter analysis
column10: and does not include social security numbers or credit card numbers
column11: the official said.The U.S. Department of Justice national security division is investigating whether cyber attacks on Democratic political organizations threatened U.S. security
column12: sources familiar with the matter said on Friday.The involvement of the Justice Department's national security division is a sign that the Obama administration has concluded that the hacking was sponsored by a state
column13: people with knowledge of the investigation said.While it is unclear exactly what material the hackers may have gained access to
column14: the third such attack on sensitive Democratic targets disclosed in the last six weeks has caused alarm in the party and beyond
column15: just over three months before the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential election.Hackers
column16: whom U.S. intelligence officials have concluded were Russian
column17: gained access to the entire network of the fundraising Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee
column19: said people familiar with the matter
column20: detailing the extent of the breach to Reuters for the first time.Cyber security experts and U.S. officials said earlier this week they had concluded
column21: based on analysis of malware and other aspects of the DNC hack
column22: that Russia engineered the release of hacked Democratic Party emails to influence the U.S. presidential election.The U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation said on Friday it was ""aware of media reporting on cyber intrusions involving multiple political entities
column23: and is working to determine the accuracy
column24: nature and scope of these matters.""""The FBI takes seriously any allegations of intrusions
column25: and we will continue to hold accountable those who pose a threat in cyberspace
column26: the agency said in an emailed statement.

column1: The hack did not involve the private email system Clinton used while she was secretary of state.Yahoo News reported on Thursday night that the FBI had warned the Clinton campaign last March that it was a target of a cyber attack involving spearphishing and had asked the campaign to turn over sensitive data to help in its investigation
column2: but that campaign lawyers rejected this request as too intrusive. A source familiar with the matter confirmed this account to Reuters. RUSSIAN HACKERS

column1: The new disclosure to Reuters that hackers gained access to the full DCCC network means they would have had access to everything on the network from emails to strategy memos and opposition research prepared to support Democratic candidates in campaigns for the House.The hack of the DCCC
column2: which is based in Washington
column3: was reported first by Reuters on Thursday
column4: ahead of Clinton's speech in Philadelphia accepting the Democratic party's nomination.

column1: Russian officials could not be immediately reached for comment.Several U.S. officials said the Obama administration has avoided publicly attributing the attacks to Russia as that might undermine Secretary of State John Kerry's effort to win Russian cooperation in the war on Islamic State in Syria.The officials said the administration fears Russian President Vladimir Putin might respond to a public move by escalating cyber attacks on U.S. targets
column2: increasing military harassment of U.S. and allied aircraft and warships in the Baltic and Black Seas
column3: and making more aggressive moves in Eastern Europe.Some officials question the approach
column4: arguing that responding more forcefully to Russia would be more effective than remaining silent.The Obama administration announced in an April 2015 executive order that it could apply economic sanctions in response to cyber attacks.

column1: TRUMP ON EMAILS
The hack on the DNC
column2: made public in June
column3: led to WikiLeaks publishing more than 19
column4: 000 emails last weekend
column5: some of them showing favoritism within the DNC for Clinton over U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz resigned on Sunday as a result
column6: creating a rocky start for the party's convention in Philadelphia this week.Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump on Wednesday invited Russia to dig up thousands of ""missing"" emails from Clinton's time at the State Department
column7: prompting Democrats to accuse him of urging foreigners to spy on Americans.On Thursday
column8: Trump said his remarks were meant as sarcasm.Earlier in the week
column9: Clinton campaign senior policy adviser Jake Sullivan had criticized Trump and called the hacking ""a national security issue.""Trump campaign spokesman Jason Miller said on Friday the reported breach showed cyber security is ""a problem wherever Hillary Clinton goes. Hopefully this time there wasn't classified or top secret information that puts American lives at risk.""In Washington
column10: the DCCC said early on Friday it had hired cyber security firm CrowdStrike to investigate. ""We have taken and are continuing to take steps to enhance the security of our network
column11: the DCCC said. ""We are cooperating with federal law enforcement with respect to their ongoing investigation.""The DCCC had no additional comment late on Friday. Officials at the DNC did not respond to requests for comment. Senator Dianne Feinstein
column12: a California Democrat and the top Democrat on the Senate intelligence committee
column13: told CNN on Friday she had not heard about the hack of the Clinton campaign.But she said: ""It wouldn't surprise me. I think it should be pretty clear that both campaigns should be aware that there's a problem out there. Everybody should be cautious."" (Additional reporting by Dustin Volz
column14: Susan Cornwell and Emily Stephenson in Washington
column15: Grant Smith in New York and Amanda Becker in Hatfield

4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN10A00N	Trump to Clinton: 'No more Mr. Nice Guy'	"
By Steve Holland
| COLORADO SPRINGS
column2: Colo.

column1: COLORADO SPRINGS
column2: Colo. U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump said he was taking the gloves off in his battle against Democrat Hillary Clinton in the race for the White House after taking a scorching from speakers at the Democratic National Convention.Trump wrapped up a five-day
column3: seven-state campaign swing in Colorado on Friday
column4: where for a fifth straight day his supporters chanted ""lock her up"" whenever he brought up Clinton's name.Trump supporters say Clinton deserves to be prosecuted for her handling of U.S. foreign policy as President Barack Obama's first-term secretary of state and for her use of a private email server while in that office.All week Trump has sought to tamp down the chants by stressing that his main goal is to simply beat Clinton in the Nov. 8 presidential election.But as the crowd chanted the slogan in Colorado Springs
column5: Trump finally relented.""I'm starting to agree with you
column6: frankly
column7: he said. ""No more Mr. Nice Guy.""

column1: In Denver later
column2: he changed his tune when he heard the chant.""I'll tell you what I'd rather do
column3: honestly
column4: is just beat her on Nov. 8 at the polls. She would be a disaster
column5: he said.Trump was a punching bag at the Democratic convention in Philadelphia
column6: which wrapped up Thursday night
column7: as speaker after speaker - including some Republicans - said he lacked the temperament to be president.

column1: Clinton herself said in her acceptance speech that the election represented a ""moment of reckoning"" for the country.In Colorado Springs
column2: Trump got sidetracked by a couple of disputes from last year as he tried to rebut a Clinton campaign ad.That ad uses video clip from Trump's attack on Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly in protest of her questioning of him at a debate of Republican presidential contenders last August when he said afterward that blood was ""coming out of her eyes
column3: coming out of her wherever.""

column1: I was talking about her nose
column2: Trump said in Colorado Springs. ""I wanted to get back on the issue of taxes"" at the debate.Trump also brought up the case of disabled New York Times reporter Serge Kovaleski
column3: whom Trump seemed to mock publicly in video used by the Clinton ad.Trump said he was depicting the reporter groveling to him.""I didn't know he was disabled. I didn't know it at all. I had no idea
column4: he said. (Reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Leslie Adler and Kim Coghill)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN105101	Clinton gets down to campaign business with Rust Belt trip	"
By Amanda Becker
| HARRISBURG
column2: Pa.

column1: HARRISBURG
column2: Pa. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton took her newly energized White House bid on the road on Friday for a tour of crucial ""Rust Belt"" states Pennsylvania and Ohio
column3: but the campaign's focus was clouded by a newly disclosed cyber attack.Reuters on Friday reported that the computer network used by Clinton's campaign
column4: which is based in Brooklyn
column5: had been hacked as part of a broad cyber attack on Democratic political organizations
column6: citing people familiar with the matter.The campaign said a data program maintained by the Democratic National Committee and used by the campaign and other entities was accessed as part of a cyber attack on the DNC. The Clinton campaign said outside experts had found no evidence that its internal systems had been compromised. On Thursday
column7: Reuters reported that the party's fundraising committee for candidates for the U.S. House of Representatives had also been breached
column8: the second such incident after last weekend's leak of DNC emails.Revelations from the DNC emails gave the Democratic convention a rocky start
column9: threatening a bid to reunify the party after a bitter primary campaign.Even so
column10: a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Friday showed Clinton leading Republican rival Donald Trump by 6 percentage points.Nearly 41 percent of likely voters favor Clinton
column13: according to the new July 25-29 online poll of 1
column15: which overlapped with the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia.After a speech Thursday night in which she became the first woman to accept a major party's presidential nomination
column16: Clinton launched a three-day bus tour of Ohio and Pennsylvania
column17: which like other Rust Belt states have been hit by the decline in U.S. manufacturing. Clinton and her vice presidential running mate
column18: U.S. Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia
column19: on Friday attended a rally at Philadelphia's Temple University
column20: toured a factory in Hatfield and ended the day in Harrisburg. They will continue onto Ohio on Saturday and Sunday. Clinton is likely to face a tough challenge in such states from Trump
column21: a New York businessman who is trying to win white working-class voters with rhetoric blasting free trade and illegal immigration.

column1: Clinton and Kaine are using the Rust Belt tour to highlight manufacturing successes and discuss how they plan to boost wages for the middle class. In the process they aim to contrast their vision for the country with the one offered by Trump.""If you're looking for a kind of pessimistic
column2: downbeat vision of America
column3: we're not your folks
column4: Clinton said in Hatfield. ""We do not buy into that dark
column5: divisive
column6: image that was presented at the Republican convention last week.""Opinion polls show a potentially tight race in Ohio and Pennsylvania
column7: both of which President Barack Obama won in the 2012 election.""The differences are stark
column8: Kaine said in Harrisburg.Clinton and Trump are essentially tied in Ohio
column9: where the Republicans held their convention last week
column10: according to an average of polls by RealClearPolitics. Clinton has a lead of 4.4 percentage points in Pennsylvania
column11: the website's average of recent polls showed.Ohio and to a lesser extent Pennsylvania are among a handful of competitive states traditionally viewed as decisive in presidential elections
column12: because they do not lean heavily Democratic or Republican.

column1: TV VIEWERSHIP LOWER FOR CLINTON
In her speech on Thursday
column2: Clinton
column4: a former first lady and U.S. senator
column5: promised to make the United States a country that works for everyone if she is elected.""We are clear-eyed about what our country is up against. But we are not afraid
column6: she said. Clinton portrayed Trump as a threat to the country
column8: ""A man you can bait with a tweet is not a man we can trust with nuclear weapons.""  Trump
column10: sent out a flurry of comments on Twitter on Friday morning lambasting media coverage of the speech as ""a joke
column11: calling the address ""very long and very boring"" and accusing Clinton of wanting to shut down ""coal mines
column12: steel plants and any other remaining manufacturing.""

column1: He campaigned in another swing state
column2: Colorado
column3: on Friday and was scheduled to visit Ohio next week. The U.S. television audience for Clinton's acceptance speech was smaller than the viewership of Trump's address a week earlier
column4: according to ratings data released on Friday.An estimated 29.8 million people watched Clinton across 10 broadcast and cable networks
column5: Nielsen data showed. Trump drew 32.2 million viewers in his July 21 address at the Republican National Convention.    Economic issues will be crucial as the White House campaign enters its final three-month stretch. The U.S. economy grew by only 1.2 percent in the second quarter
column6: far less than expected
column7: the Commerce Department said on Friday. During the Rust Belt trip
column8: Clinton will detail her pledge to raise wages and create jobs by unveiling a major infrastructure package within the first 100 days of her presidency
column9: and encouraging companies to invest in workers.   The start of the Democratic convention was overshadowed by the resignation of DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz
column10: who quit over leaked emails showing party officials favored Clinton over her primary rival Bernie Sanders
column11: a U.S. senator of Vermont.Cyber security experts and U.S. officials said on Monday there was evidence that Russia engineered the release of the  emails in order to influence the election. The Kremlin has denied the accusations.Yet another hack came to light on Thursday
column12: when four people familiar with the matter told Reuters that the Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating a cyber attack against the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee
column13: which raises money for Democrats running for the U.S. House of Representatives. The DCCC confirmed on Friday that it had been the target of a cyber security incident.  (Reporting by Jonathan Allen
column19: Alana Wise and Lisa Richwine; Writing by Alistair Bell and Jonathan Oatis; Editing by Frances Kerry and Leslie Adler; Editing by Frances Kerry and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-wisconsin-idUSKCN1092O0	Federal judge strikes down parts of Wisconsin voter laws	"
By Dan Whitcomb
A federal judge on Friday struck down a string of Wisconsin voting restrictions passed by the Republican-led legislature and ordered the state to revamp its voter identification rules
column2: finding that they disenfranchised minority voters.U.S. District Judge James Peterson
column3: ruling in a legal challenge to the laws by two liberal groups
column4: said he could not overturn the entire voter ID law because a federal appeals court had already found such restrictions to be constitutional.But Peterson
column5: in his 119-page ruling
column6: said the requirements that Wisconsin voters show either a photo identification or go through a special petition process had unfairly burdened minorities and needed to be reformed or replaced before the November presidential election.""To put it bluntly
column7: Wisconsin's strict version of voter ID law is a cure worse than the disease
column8: the judge wrote. Peterson left the voting rules intact for the Aug 9. primary elections for federal
column10: saying to change them less than two weeks in advance would be disruptive.

column1: But his ruling was expected to impact the November presidential election in Wisconsin
column2: which could prove a crucial battleground state for Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump.Peterson also struck down as unconstitutional limits on in-person absentee voting
column3: residency requirements and a ban on using expired student identification.Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker said in a tweet that he was ""disappointed in the decision by an activist federal judge"" and expected to file an appeal.

column1: A spokesman for One Wisconsin Institute
column2: one of the two groups which filed the challenge
column3: hailed Peterson's ruling as ""a huge win not only for the plaintiffs but for democracy itself."" Wisconsin is one of several Republican-led states that have passed such voter ID laws in recent years amid fear of fraudulent voting by illegal immigrants and others. Among the nine states with the strictest laws
column4: insisting on state-issued photo identification for voters
column5: are Georgia
column6: Indiana

column1: A U.S. appeals court judge earlier this month ruled the Texas law discriminatory. The judge sent the case back to the lower court to examine whether the law had a discriminatory purpose and also asked the court for a short-term fix for the November general election.Republicans say voter ID laws are needed to prevent voter fraud. Democrats say the laws are really intended to make it harder for poor African-Americans and Latinos
column2: who tend to vote Democrat
column3: to vote. (Reporting by Dan Whitcomb; Editing by James Dalgleish
column4: Leslie Adler and Bernard Orr)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-defense-missiles-idUSKCN1092MS	U.S. Air Force asks industry for proposals to replace nuclear missiles	"
By David Alexander
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The U.S. Air Force asked industry on Friday for proposals to replace the Minuteman III intercontinental ballistic missile and the nuclear cruise missile as the military moves ahead with a costly modernization of its aging atomic weapons systems.The Air Force said in a statement it expected to award up to two contracts for a new ICBM weapons system
column2: or ground-based strategic deterrent
column3: sometime next summer or fall. It also expected to award up to two contracts in the same time frame for a new nuclear cruise missile
column4: or long-range standoff weapon.Modernization of the U.S. nuclear force is expected to cost more than $350 billion over the next decade as the United States works to replace its aging systems
column5: including bombs
column6: nuclear bombers
column7: missiles and submarines. Some analysts estimate the cost of modernization at $1 trillion over 30 years.The new ICBM system would be a follow-on to the Minuteman missile
column8: whose launch systems and physical infrastructure first became operational in the mid-1960s. The system has been upgraded over the years
column9: but much of the infrastructure is original

column1: The most recent versions of the Minuteman III date from the late 1990s and early 2000s and had an intended 20-year life span
column2: the Air Force said. The missile will ""face increased operational and sustainment challenges until it can be replaced
column3: it said.""This request for proposals is the next step to ensuring the nation's ICBM leg of the nuclear triad remains safe
column4: secure and effective
column5: said Major General Scott Jansson
column6: who leads the Air Force program office for strategic systems.

column1: Opponents of replacing the nuclear cruise missile have argued that its missions could be handled by other legs of the triad. Others say it is an unnecessary expense at a time of shrinking budgets and smaller deployed nuclear arsenals.The military insists the new cruise missile is needed to enable older bombers to deliver nuclear weapons to targets whose air space is heavily defended and difficult to reach with gravity bombs.
The missile is ""needed to replace the aging air launched cruise missile
column2: which has far exceeded its originally planned service life ... and is required to support our B-52 bomber fleet
column3: Admiral Cecil Haney
column4: the head of U.S. Strategic Command
column5: told lawmakers earlier this year. (Reporting by David Alexander)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-cuba-dissidents-usa-idUSKCN1092IW	U.S. worried about hunger-striking Cuban dissidents: State Department	"
WASHINGTON The United States is concerned about the physical well-being of hunger-striking activists in Cuba and is closely watching their situation
column2: the U.S. State Department said on Friday.""We stand in solidarity with those who advocate for human rights and fundamental freedoms
column3: including freedom of expression and the right to peaceful assembly
column4: State Department spokesman John Kirby told a briefing.""We have raised our concerns directly with the Cuban government
column5: both in Washington and Havana
column6: he added.

column1: Kirby said Washington was particularly concerned about the health of dissidents Carlos Amel Oliva
column2: who leads the youth wing of a Cuban dissident group
column3: and Guillermo Farinas. Farinas began a hunger strike earlier this month calling
column4: for Raul Castro's government to end torture and human rights abuses. He was taken to Arnaldo Milian Castro Hospital in the city of Santa Clara on Thursday after becoming extremely weak and fainting eight days into the strike
column5: The Miami Herald reported.

column1: Farinas and about 20 other rights activists are on hunger-strike in Cuba.
(Reporting by Arshad Mohammed; Writing by David Alexander; Editing by Sandra Maler)"
9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-politics-menendez-idUSKCN1091RF	U.S. court rejects NJ Senator Menendez's bid to end corruption case	"
By Jonathan Stempel
A federal appeals court on Friday refused to dismiss a corruption indictment against Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey
column2: rejecting the Democrat's claim that the U.S. Constitution shielded him from prosecution.The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said prosecutors could pursue charges that Menendez accepted campaign donations and gifts
column3: including a stay in a Caribbean villa and private jet flights from a wealthy friend
column4: Florida ophthalmologist Salomon Melgen
column5: in exchange for using his office to lobby on his behalf.""Members of Congress are not to be 'super-citizens' immune from criminal liability
column6: Circuit Judge Thomas Ambro wrote for a three-judge panel of the Philadelphia-based appeals court.Friday's decision means the case could eventually be headed for trial
column7: and could complicate Democrats' efforts to regain control of the U.S. Senate after the Nov. 8 election.If Menendez
column9: were forced to give up the seat he has held since 2006
column12: could under New Jersey law appoint a temporary replacement.The senator has pledged to stay in office while defending himself
column13: but has given up his post as the ranking Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.Abbe Lowell
column15: said the senator intends to ask the entire appeals court to review Friday's decision
column18: appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court.The decision is ""another step in the legal process that
column19: at the end of the day
column20: will show that Senator Menendez has always acted in accordance with the law
column21: Lowell said in a statement. ""The Senator remains confident that he will be vindicated.""Peter Carr
column22: a U.S. Department of Justice spokesman

column1: LOBBYING OR POLICYMAKING?
In an indictment unveiled in April 2015
column2: Menendez was accused of accepting bribes from Melgen in exchange for interceding in various matters on his friend's behalf.Prosecutors said these included an $8.9 million Medicare billing dispute
column3: and a contract dispute with the Dominican Republic in which Menendez encouraged the State Department to intervene.Menendez and Melgen have pleaded not guilty to the respective charges they faced in the 22-count indictment.Last September
column4: U.S. District Judge William Walls in Newark
column5: New Jersey
column6: dismissed four bribery counts but left most of the government's case intact.

column1: In his appeal
column2: Menendez argued that his actions were protected by the Constitution's ""speech or debate"" clause
column3: which offers broad protection to members of Congress against prosecution for actions they undertake as legislators.Ambro
column4: however
column5: said Menendez's actions amounted to ""essentially lobbying on behalf of a particular party
column6: and thus outside the ""safe harbor"" provided in the Constitution.There is ""a sufficient basis for the district court's conclusion that the predominant purpose of the challenged acts was to pursue a political resolution to Dr. Melgen's disputes
column7: Ambro wrote. ""It was not to engage in true legislative oversight or otherwise influence broad matters of policy.""MCDONNELL

column1: Lowell had argued that Walls should have focused on what actually went on at the meetings in question
column2: saying the record reflected that ""high-level policy discussions"" had taken place.Ambro said Menendez remains free to argue that his efforts were directed toward influencing policy
column3: and the government still has the burden at trial of proving otherwise.""The evidence in favor of Senator Menendez will no doubt channel forcefully his position at trial
column4: the judge wrote.Friday's decision came one month after the Supreme Court unanimously overturned the bribery convictions of former Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell.That court said routine political activities such as arranging meetings or reaching out to public officials generally could not form a basis for criminal prosecutions.The 3rd Circuit focused mainly on the speech or debate clause
column5: and did not mention McDonnell. Lowell said that case raised ""important"" issues that need to be addressed.The case is U.S. v. Menendez
column6: 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals
column7: No. 15-3459. (Reporting by Jonathan Stempel in New York; Editing by Bill Trott and Jonathan Oatis)"
